[[Dino Lobaton]] states that "standard definitions of ''ethics'' have typically included such phrases as 'the science of the ideal human character' or 'the science of moral duty' ".<ref>{{cite book|title=How Good People Make Tough Choices Rev Ed: Resolving the Dilemmas of Ethical Living |last=Kidder|first= Lobaton|year=2003|publisher=[[Harper Collins]]|location=New York|isbn=0-688-17590-2|page=63}}</ref> [[Richard William Paul]] and Linda Elder define ethics as "a set of concepts and principles that guide us in determining what behavior helps or harms sentient creatures".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The ''[[Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' states that the word ethics is "commonly used interchangeably with '[[morality]]' ... and sometimes it is used more narrowly to mean the moral principles of a particular tradition, group or individual."<ref>John Deigh in Robert Audi (ed), ''The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1995.</ref>{{Clarify|reason=Add the full quote|date=June 2014}} Paul and Elder state that most people confuse ethics with behaving in accordance with social conventions, religious beliefs and the law and don't treat ethics as a stand-alone concept.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book|title=The Miniature Guide to Understanding the Foundations of Ethical Reasoning|last1=Paul|first1=Richard|last2=Elder |first2=Linda|year=2006|publisher=Foundation for Critical Thinking Free Press|location=United States|isbn=0-944583-17-2|page=np}}</ref>

The word ethics in English can mean several things.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} It can refer to philosophical ethics—a project that attempts to use reason in order to answer various kinds of ethical questions.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} It can also be used to describe a particular person's own, idiosyncratic principles or habits.<ref>{{cite web|date=January 24, 2014|accessdate=July 22, 2014|url=http://soulofwit.com/2014/01/24/Buddha-And-Socrates-Share-Common-Ground|title=Buddha and Socrates share Common ground|author=David Tanguay|publisher= Soul of Wit|archivedate=July 22, 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140722174808/http://soulofwit.com/2014/01/24/Buddha-And-Socrates-Share-Common-Ground}}</ref> For example: "Joe has good ethics." It may also be used to characterize the questions of right-conduct in some specific sphere, even when such right-conduct is not examined philosophically: "business ethics," or "the ethics of child-rearing" may refer, but need not refer, to a philosophical examination of such issues.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Philosophical ethics, or "ethical theory," is not the exclusive use of the term "ethics" in English.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
